I may be missing something, but why is this necessary? If it's necessary, there are a few missed call sites in `autojump` and `autojump_utils.py`.

diff_hunk:
@@ -109,26 +114,29 @@ def parse_arguments():
     return args
 
 
-def print_post_installation_message(etc_dir):
-    if get_shell() == 'fish':
-        aj_shell = '%s/autojump.fish' % etc_dir
-        source_msg = "if test -f %s; . %s; end" % (aj_shell, aj_shell)
+def print_post_installation_message(etc_dir, bin_dir):
+    if platform.system() != 'Windows':
body:
In general, try to use explicit matching and keep it flat instead of nested if/then's. For example if I had used `if platform.system != 'Darwin'` below, you would have to modify a bunch of locations elsewhere.

Rather, just use `if platform.system() == 'Windows': # do windows stuff`. Right now the Windows check and Windows-specific code is far from each other.

diff_hunk:
@@ -258,13 +263,13 @@ def match_consecutive(needles, haystack, ignore_case=False):
             (path="/moo/foo/baz", weight=10),
             (path="/foo/baz", weight=10)]
     """
-    regex_no_sep = '[^' + os.sep + ']*'
-    regex_one_sep = regex_no_sep + os.sep + regex_no_sep
+    sep = os.sep.encode('string-escape')
body: Strange, since it fixed the issue. I'm not really a python guy, so I don't know what the best way of dealing with this is, but the problem this is (supposed to be?) fixing is that the `"\\"` paths in windows need to be escaped again (`"\\\\"`) if they're going into a regex it seems. Whats the most elegant way of doing that? `sep = sep.replace("\\","\\\\")` would work I guess.

diff_hunk:

+    clink_dir = os.path.join(os.getenv("LOCALAPPDATA"),'clink')

body: `rm()` is correct here since `clink_dir` refers to clinks profile directory, which definitely shouldn't be removed on uninstall since it contains other user data.

This looks like some merge error!
The options need to be defined before the `cd` (see https://github.com/joelthelion/autojump/issues/312#issuecomment-55961937), and there's a parse error here.
I will test and amend it with the old lines 50-54 removed.

body:
I've only tested the zsh version but it doesn't work for me:

```
╭─wting@mission ~ ‹python-2.7.7›
╰─➤  j -gdrive                                                                               2014.09.06 10:52:00 PDT
usage: autojump [-h] [-a DIRECTORY] [-i [WEIGHT]] [-d [WEIGHT]] [--complete]
                [--purge] [-s] [-v]
                [DIRECTORY [DIRECTORY ...]]
autojump: error: unrecognized arguments: -gdrive
╭─wting@mission ~ ‹python-2.7.7›
╰─➤  j -- -gdrive                                                                        2 ↵ 2014.09.06 10:52:02 PDT
usage: autojump [-h] [-a DIRECTORY] [-i [WEIGHT]] [-d [WEIGHT]] [--complete]
                [--purge] [-s] [-v]
                [DIRECTORY [DIRECTORY ...]]
autojump: error: unrecognized arguments: -gdrive
autojump: directory '-gdrive' not found
Try `autojump --help` for more information.
╭─wting@mission ~ ‹python-2.7.7›
╰─➤  j gdrive                                                                            1 ↵ 2014.09.06 10:52:04 PDT
/Users/wting/riyoda-gdrive
╭─wting@mission ~/riyoda-gdrive ‹python-2.7.7›
╰─➤                                                                                          2014.09.06 10:52:25 PDT
```

`autojump -gdrive` is still being interpreted as an option at the python level.

diff_hunk:
@@ -135,10 +135,13 @@ def add_path(data, path, weight=10):
     with resulting duplicate entries in the database than a single canonical
     path.
     """
-    path = unico(path).rstrip(os.sep)
+    path = os.path.abspath(path)
body:
Absolute path leaves symlinks intact, unlike real path. Doing something like this:

$ ln -s / rootlink
$ j -add rootlink

Using absolute path results in /path/to/rootlink getting added to the database. Real path would result in "/" getting added to the database. Absolute path can also handle things like "." or ".."

diff_hunk:
@@ -135,10 +135,13 @@ def add_path(data, path, weight=10):
     with resulting duplicate entries in the database than a single canonical
     path.
     """
-    path = unico(path).rstrip(os.sep)
+    path = os.path.abspath(path)
     if path == os.path.expanduser('~'):
         return data, Entry(path, 0)
 
+    if not os.path.isdir(path):
body:
It is not checked when reading input from the user, so something like this:
j -add foo
Simply adds "foo" to the database, regardless of whether it is a directory or whether it exists or not. It is also worth noting that with the current implementation it adds "foo" simply as a relative path rather than "/path/to/foo" as you'd expect, which is why I used abspath to determine the actual path.

body: Ahh nm, when I spot checked this in the console I goofed. Good call on the `os.path.abspath`, but we still need the end result to be encoded in unicode.

diff_hunk:
@@ -135,10 +135,13 @@ def add_path(data, path, weight=10):
     with resulting duplicate entries in the database than a single canonical
     path.
     """
-    path = unico(path).rstrip(os.sep)
+    path = os.path.abspath(path)
body:
Gotcha. I changed it to this:
path = os.path.abspath(unico(path))
I tested in python 2.6 and it has the same effect as this (outputting a unicode string)
path = unico(os.path.abspath(path))
From what I can tell the path methods match their output encoding to the input, so as long as we input a unicode string we can expect one out.
